title: Elementary proof that a non-orientable manifold of real dimension  does not admit a quasi-complex structure.
body: Is there an easy proof that a non-orientable real surface  does not admit a quasi-complex structure? The proof I know is to observe that any quasi-complex structure on a real surface  necessarily satisfies the integrability condition  of the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem, because  is a -dimensional complex vector bundle, and the bracket  is alternating, i.e. it vanishes on . So by the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem,  admits a complex structure, and complex manifolds have to be orientable. However, the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem is a deep theorem and feels a bit overkill. Also I don't really see why there cannot be a quasi-complex structure. Is there a more elementary proof to convince myself?

title: Riemann's definition of the zeta function
body: I am having trouble understanding Riemann's definition of the zeta function, and I will need to give a brief summary here before I can get to my question. In his 1859 paper, Riemann derived the integral representation  that is valid for , and then modified the integral in order to define a function that is defined for all complex values of , except , where it has a simple pole. The extension is given by  where  is a "Hankel contour", that is, a path that travels from  at a small distance  above the positive -axis, circles around the origin once in counterclockwise direction with a small radius , and returns to  traveling at distance  below the positive real axis. Taking the limit as  and  one can see that the integral  becomes  and then the rest follows easily from known identities satisfied by the Gamma function.  While the original real integral over  is clearly divergent if , the contour integral over  is defined for all complex , because the path stays away from the singularity at  and from the branch cut along the positive -axis. My problem is understanding why the integral over  does not depend on  and , so that we can keep them at a safe positive distance from the singularities for the definition, but we can take the limit for the purpose of evaluating the integral. I know that by Cauchy's theorem we can modify a path of integration (without changing the value of the integral) starting and ending at the same point as long as we do not cross any singularity, but this path starts and ends at infinity, so I am not sure how to rigorously proceed using Cauchy's theorem. Even if I start the path at  and end it at  for some large , the path starting and ending points change as  changes.

title: Determinant not equal to volume error (closed)
body: The determinant of a  matrix  is the volume of a parallelopiped with its three sides as the vectors whose tails rest on origin and heads at the coordinates  and  . The determinant of this matrix can be simplified to .  Proof: Subtracting columnfrom column 2, and putting that in column  2,   rearranging the terms,  taking out the common terms  and ,  expanding the terms  and    taking out the common term      As the  coordinate of the heads of these three vectors is , the head of these vectors lies in a plane perpendicular to the -axis and a distance of  unit away from the origin. (If we connect these three points, we get a triangle.) This plane will cut the parallelopiped into two equal triangular pyramids whose base lies in the plane. The perpendicular distance from the base of the pyramid to the tip is  unit. The volume of the required parallelogram is the sum of the volume of the two triangular pyramids. . The height is  units. The area of a triangle is, by Shoelace formula,  where the vertices of the triangle are   The vertices of the required traingle has the coordinates  and . So the area of the triangle,  which, as shown above, can be simplified to  So, the volume is   But, shouldn't the volume be equal to the determinant which is  ? So this definitely doesn't work for the third quadrant.) (2) Expanding upon the stuff in the parantheses up there, a possible explanation is that while doing trig substitutions, the angle is always a principal angle of the inverse trigonometric operation on whatever you're making the substitution. Is there such a rule?
